Primary Number : 7… @sambitbal @cricketaakash We have to find a way though,beyond this decision, because in a vast majority of cases the cameras won't be able to judge if a low catch was clean or wasn't. We have had lots of violent twitter outbursts over that too... @KadakiaVicky And replaced by? @pranay_karnik The issue isn't a blurred picture. It is the extra dimension which, for some reason, nobody is inclined to understand! Ah, a measured response! As things stand, it is mandatory. It is a grey area, almost impossible for an umpire to judge. But an "unsighted" call is very difficult to resolve with even the best cameras. Everything looks not-out! We may not like it but there is no solution for now https://t.co/nz82wmlQAG I thought the ball touched the ground & said so on air. This tweet was to explain why a soft signal was introduced in the first place & why technology is not yet ready to give conclusive answers in most cases. England will fancy chasing this The reason an umpire has to give a soft signal is documented. On the replays, even clean catches look not out because it is a 2D image of a 3D event. Primary Number… Ashwin is a different person so the presenter must play to those strengths  so that that part of the presentation becomes interesting too. It is never a competition between the host and the guest but whatever is right for the viewer. I thought we did that with both Pant & Ashwin Haha, been reading some of your responses. The job of a presenter is to make the player feel comfortable so that his personality comes through for viewers and the presentation becomes interesting as a result. Pant is a character and you have to let that side come out too. The bowling has been excellent but the batting is listless too. I suspect the series was lost in the mind long before this innings started. 67 overs left. English shoulders were drooping this morning. We might even have a result today. Oh @Sundarwashi5, wasn't to be but very well played. There will be more centuries. It was batting of the highest class. @vern158 Don't remember anything like that... Oh! #OnThisDay 50 years ago, #SunilGavaskar made his Test debut in 1971

Watch: @bhogleharsha pays… 50 years since the great Sunil Gavaskar made his test debut and announced himself to the world. My elder brother @bhogle used to keep a scrap book and that is how I got drawn in. Gavaskar soon became a symbol of hope for us. I followed Indian cricket through his performances. RT @DDIndialive: Cricket commentator @bhogleharsha, in a special chat with @Imabhimahajan, shares his journey from chemical engineering to… RT @cricbuzz: Pant (101) & #Washington (60*) rain fire on England as India end Day 2 on top with a lead of 89. @bhogleharsha & @MichaelVaug… Well played too @Sundarwashi5. Such composure for someone so young and inexperienced. Already, in such a short career, he has walked into difficult situations and handled them like a veteran. I particularly enjoyed the first 50. Well crafted, played with responsibility, aware India needed to catch up with England. It showed his growth as a batsman. What joy to see young @RishabhPant17 bat. I did not think I would see a reverse sweep to Anderson with the new ball when a century was there for the taking. He will keep us on the edge of our seats and will be great for our game. England are trying hard but are a bowler short. Bess hasn't been test class and Stokes is absolutely spent. The debate on whether or not the law is good is for another time. The umpires have to interpret the law as it stands. And given the allowed margin of error in ball-tracking, more than half the ball has to hit the bottom of the bails for a decision to be overturned @vaitheek @kartikmurali You are indeed right. We were talking about spinners. Cheers For a decision to be overturned, more than 50% of the ball has to hit the top of the stump. In Pant's case, a major part of the ball was hitting the bails but not enough was hitting the top of the stump. Watching @benstokes38 this morning was to realise, once again, what a special cricketer he is In Mohd Siraj, India have found a whole-hearted trier. He's nippy, has the outswinger, the ball that nips back in, a good bouncer and a wonderful attitude. He was brilliant today RT @BloodDonorsIn: #Chittoor

The question is: will a bowler be allowed to do it. Whether be can or can't is a separate issue. And batsmen play late and they charge, play off front foot and back, loft the ball or sweep it. The trickery and skill must lie within a legal challenge and its acceptance. https://t.co/z6duRD5rND The contest in our game is simple. The bowler's challenge is the ball he bowls & the field he sets. The batsman's response: counter that with his bat while respecting the challenge that is thrown at him. Within this, a player is free to innovate. Anything outside this is unfair The reverse sweep is fine because a batsman doesn't change his grip. He is still a right hander and that is a valid skill. But a switch hit makes the field setting useless because you are bowling to a different kind of batsman. The umpire says "right arm over". After that, the bowler is free to bowl anything as long as he isn't chucking and is right arm over. The batsman takes guard as a right hander & he is free to play any shot as long as he is right handed. For the switch hit, he becomes left handed https://t.co/DzmlAN4umT I agree completely with Ian Chappell. The reason an umpire has to give a soft signal is documented. On the replays, even clean catches look not out because it is a 2D image of a 3D event. Hence, umpires look at whether the fingers are under the ball. It is a grey area but tech has no answer for now. Need 3D cameras?

First thoughts. Ball seems to be stopping just a bit (noticed the puff of dust?) And Olly Stone is very impressive.

This is the spin combination India would have gone in with in the first test if Axar Patel had been fit. Siraj is a fine exponent of reverse swing so could be effective and to that extent, the absence of Bumrah might not be as big on this surface.

England are trying to create a set-up where they can have 7-8 batsmen, 2-3 keepers, 6-7 pacers all of whom are capable of being in the test XI and who can be moved around without affecting the playing combination too much. It has happened in white ball cricket, but not in tests
Big toss to win if the pitch report is indeed accurate. Good to see Kuldeep back in and I suspected Bumrah might be rested. 7 changes across the teams.....

I am keen to know if the players rested either wanted to, or needed to, be rested. If they wanted to play, you end up making them insecure; a state of mind which isn't good for anybody.

@debayansen @captainshanky Yes

@cricketaakash Been saying for a while that to achieve the right balance, either Jadeja or Ashwin, or a keeper, had to evolve into a no 6. But that compromise, if either wasn't as good as a batsman at no 6, would require a pretty good no 7 & no 8. This makes it another reason to watch the game
@captainshanky So essentially we are telling Pant that he isn't much good against spin standing up and he isn't much good with a pink ball moving around?

This is a big statement of confidence in some players and on the approach to playing a test series. I will be very keen to see consistency because that also signifies conviction and creates confidence in players.

If Shaw had to be out and Gill in, the like for like replacement for Kohli (if possible at all!) was Rahul. But in principle, India have decided they want 5 bowlers. It is a big punt on the batting skills of Pant and Jadeja. I hope it isn't the outcome of needing to play Jadeja

We now have two confused keepers because they have been given conflicting signals. Pant was, effectively, told he was the overseas keeper and Saha the home keeper. That changed at Adelaide and now suddenly, it has changed again. The principle always dictates the selection (cont)

The absence of Shami and Ishant means they feel the need for a 5th bowler which is either an admission that they don't trust 4 or that they expect the track to turn later. Since Jadeja cannot play at 6 in Australia, it means sacrificing the keeper for someone who can bat (cont)

Thread. India's team for the 2nd test is an admission that they got many things wrong in the first test. Especially with the keeper & opener. They must think Shaw is short on confidence because dropping a player after 2 innings means you aren't giving him time to learn (cont)
Merry Christmas to all. May it lead to kinder, happier tomorrows.

What a day for Natarajan. What a story. If you are 29, don't lose hope. Wish him well.

@captainshanky It goes against the very ethic of our sport. Because it is dangerous or risky doesn't make it right. You have to respect the guidelines within which the ball is delivered and then use your skill to counter it.
@captainshanky Never know what kind of bowler turns up! The question is: will a bowler be allowed to do it. Whether be can or can't is a separate issue.
And batsmen play late and they charge, play off front foot and back, loft the ball or sweep it. The trickery and skill must lie within a legal challenge and its acceptance. https://t.co/z6duRD5rND

The contest in our game is simple. The bowler's challenge is the ball he bowls & the field he sets. The batsman's response: counter that with his bat while respecting the challenge that is thrown at him. Within this, a player is free to innovate. Anything outside this is unfair

The reverse sweep is fine because a batsman doesn't change his grip. He is still a right hander and that is a valid skill. But a switch hit makes the field setting useless because you are bowling to a different kind of batsman.

The umpire says "right arm over". After that, the bowler is free to bowl anything as long as he isn't chucking and is right arm over. The batsman takes guard as a right hander & he is free to play any shot as long as he is right handed. For the switch hit, he becomes left handed https://t.co/DzmlAN4umT

I agree completely with Ian Chappell. I have long said that the switch hit is unfair because the bowler sets the field for a right handed batsman who cannot then become a left hander. A right arm bowler should then be allowed to run in and bowl left handed too.
@NMWoolrich @VenkyMysore Haha. True.

If you have heard the #MissionISRO podcast, you will see it was a classic underdog story & I was blown away by how much was achieved with such limited resources. The audacity and the zeal was inspiring. Have you ever felt that you were an underdog in any situation? @spotifyindia

The last week began with so many possibilities, with every match being crucial to play-off aspirations. And every match has been one-sided! The same team has dominated and been crushed! The tail-end of the #IPL is a different beast.

What an extraordinary turnaround there has been for @SunRisers since Saha arrived. It has unleashed @davidwarner31 & made him,once again, the feared batsman who bosses the #IPL every year. The identical twin who was pottering around earlier has been revealed. The original is back
Good to see that @SunRisers are not pottering around and playing safe given it is not a huge target. They have to stay ahead of the asking rate as far as possible. These can be tricky chases

No praise too high for Zimbabwe to beat a team like Pakistan playing at home over 50 overs. Players like Taylor, Williams, Reza, Muzarabani just keep producing these performances. Keen to see more of Hasnain now.
We are seeing from @Wriddhipops why a keeper is a spinner's best friend
So we  don't know too much more than we did! https://t.co/WdQWtke3FV
Rohit Sharma at the toss! Yes there is a qualification at stake but this is huge news. All eyes on him and his fitness

You were very good for Australia @ShaneRWatson33 but you were especially good for the @IPL. Those early years, the MVPs, the 2018 & 2019 finals.There is a small group of overseas stars who enriched the #IPL & you will always be in the list. Go well, hopefully our paths will cross
In all fairness @RCBTweets and @DelhiCapitals deserved to make the play-offs. But isn't it amazing that the bottom placed team had to overturn just one result to be in contention! Awesome tournament.
Fair to say that both #RCB and #DC are going through now. #KKR to await the outcome of #MIvsSRH
#DelhiCapitals happier of the two sides on the field. #KKR, watching no doubt, the unhappiest! They don't want a close game. Remember, a close game means both #DC and #RCB go through
Loved the speeds that Ashwin bowled at. If there is no dew, none so far, that might be the way to go for RCB who have three spinners today
RCB need a powerful striker below Virat and AB. Will free those two. That was the role for Shivam Dube and Morris.
So Ashwin won't come back on the field. India's strained hamstring tally is growing. Hopefully it is a precaution.

What an extraordinary cricket match. The occasion can affect the very best. And what a brilliant, topsy-turvy #IPL this has been
#DC and #RCB fans watching more closely now than #RR fans
